column1: Usurpations of the Federal Government have been presented
column2: not in a spirit of hostility
column3: but as a warning to the people against the dangers by which their liberties are beset. When the war ceased
column4: the pretext on which it had been waged could no longer be alleged. The emancipation proclamation of Mr. Lincoln
column7: he humorously admitted to be a nullity
column8: had acquired validity by the action of the highest authority known to our institutions—the people assembled in their several State Conventions. The soldiers of the Confederacy had laid down their arms
column9: had in good faith pledged themselves to abstain from further hostile operations
column10: and had peacefully dispersed to their homes; there could not
column12: have been further dread of them by the Government of the United States. The plea of necessity could
column14: no longer exist for hostile demonstration against the people and States of the deceased Confederacy. Did vengeance
column16: subside? Did real peace and the restoration of the States to their former rights and positions follow
column17: as was promised on the restoration of the Union?
